metadata.title: Nano FexZn1−xO as a tuneable and efficient photocatalyst for solar powered degradation of Bisphenol A from water

sections.text:
M AN
US CR
AC CE
PT ED
1
Currently, the photocatalytic nanomaterials performing under solar radiation have gained worldwide attentions due to increasing environmental deterioration. For utilizing the sunlight for degradation of emerging pollutants it is important to develop visible active photocatalysts. This laboratory scale work reports magnetic and optically active nano-photocatalyst FexZn1xO(x=0.01, 0.03, 0.05) synthesized by solution combustion method. High resolution transmission microscopy suggests a slight degradation in the crystallite structure with Fe doping. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis shows the presence of intrinsic defects in the crystal structure. Zn resides in +2 and and Fe in +3 oxidation state. Optical band gap studies were made with band structure for each doped sample. The photoctalytic activity of the samples was tested by solar degradation of noxious pollutant Bisphenol A. 99.1% of bisphenol was degraded in 90min in presence of Fe0.03Zn0.97O under synergistic adsorption and photocatalysis. The results were analyzed in terms of total organic carbon, chemical oxygen demand, effect of scavengers, gas chromatography-mass spectrometry and reusability. In presence of Fe0.03Zn0.97O, 45.3% of total organic carbon was removed and chemical oxygen demand was reduced to 11.2%. A possible mechanism with structures of the intermediates has been given. Effect of scavengers reveal that hydroxyl radicals are major reactive oxygen species involved which is also supported by the band edge positions. The research work promises to design highly photo-active tuneable magnetic photocatalysts for solar powered degradation of contaminants of emerging concern with a simple and costeffective approach.

Keywords: Bisphenol; photodegradation; optical tuning; adsorption; zinc oxide
1. Introduction
Recently the dense industrialization all over the world has threatened the natural water systems. The waste water contain varieties of emerging contaminants such as endocrine disruptor phenols derivatives, estrogens and chloro compounds (Kumar et al., 2017; Liu et al., 2016). Bisphenol A (C15H16O2) (BPA) is an important phenol derivative which have been used as precursor material in the manufacture of polycarbonate, epoxy and polysulfonate resins (Hengstler et al., 2011). The huge use of BPA has led to an easy access to interfere with living system as it is a main part of plastic accessories used for domestic use in daily life (Zhang et al., 2014). BPA, due to its endocrine disruptor activity, it is highly toxic to marine organism in the range of 1-10 mgL-1 (Kang et al., 2006) and potential danger to aquatic species in very low concentrations of 0.1-10 ngL-1 (Belgiorno, et al 2007). The endocrine disruptors have been now found at level of ng/L– g/L in rivers and waste water (Zacharakis et al 2013). In addition BPA has also adverse effects on human reproductive system (Guo et al., 2009). Therefore, it is indispensable to develop an effective strategy for rapid removal and efficient mineralization for BPA from aquatic environment. In recent years variety of operations have come into existence for BPA elimination such as advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) (Sharma et al., 2015), chemical oxidation (Potakis et al., 2017), adsorption (Lee et al., 2005), and biological processes (Hu et al., 2002). However it has been recognized that the degradation of organic pollutants may lead to the formation of some byproducts which may be more toxic as compare to parent (Kant et al., 2014). Thus it is extensively important to achieve complete mineralization of BPA into CO2 and H2O.
In last decades, semiconductor based photocatalysis has attracted much attention for environmental remediation (Kumar et al., 2016). As they are capable for virtuous harnessing of solar energy, they are eco-friendly tools for the mineralization of many noxious pollutants (Van de Walle, 2000). In semiconductor photocatalysis which is most effective advanced oxidation process, electron hole pairs are generated on exposure to photons (Sharma et al., 2017) However charge recombination leads to negative results (Karimi-Shamsabadia et al., 2016). For effective degradation of pollutants lower recombination and higher photon absorption is required. In addition electrons must be able to form superoxide radical anions and similarly holes should be able to produce hydroxyl radicals. Hence designing of photocatalyst can lead to better degradation results. The recombination process can be
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
3
lowered by various techniques as doping of catalyst (Hossein et al., 2017) and hetero-junction formation (Nezamzadeh-Ejhieh et al., 2015; Azimi et al., 2015) In addition providing support to semiconductor as inorganic substrates (Zabihi-Mobarakeh et al., 2015) and biopolymers (Kumar et al., 2015) and formation mixed semiconductors (Bahrami et al., 2014) are the other strategies. Combining of semiconductors or mixed oxides leads to better charge separation, mobility of charge carriers leading to reduced recombination as in ZnO-SnO2 (Khodami et al., 2015) Zinc oxide and titanium dioxide have been exploited the most and are still used for various environmental applications especially photodegradation of organic pollutants as drugs (AbaGuevara et al., 2017) dyes (Dhiman et al., 2013) and others (Türkyılmaz et al., 2017). Magnetic photocatalysts have an advantage over separation which can be achieved by coupling of these photocatalysts with ferrites or Fe3O4 and doping by magnetic transition metalsas Fe, Ni and Co. Recently, even nanosize ZnO has been reported for exhibiting room temperature ferromagnetism (Ekhande et al., 2013). To achieve room temperature ferromagnetism, Ni, Co, Cu, Cr, Mn, and Fe has been widely used as dopant for ZnO, so that these systems can be used as spintronics. Out of all these studied systems, Fe doped ZnO is most controversial system (Dhiman et al., 2013; Kant et al., 2013). ZnO based diluted magnetic semiconductors (DMSs) have also attracted considerable attention due to their potential applications in the emerging fields of optoelectronics, spinpolarised light emitting diodes (LEDs) and photovoltics (Liu et al., 2014; Wang et al., 2010). Innovation has been in progress for modifying simpler photocatalysts as coupling of TiO2 with N-doped grapheme (Hossein et al., 2017) or preparation of ZnO/Zn photoanodes for pollutant degradation (Lee et al., 2016). TiO2 and ZnO based photocatalysts have also been employed earlier from removal of BPA and other endocrine disruptors like N-doped TiO2 (Venkatachalam et al., 2006), Rh/TiO2 (Repousi et al., 2017) and (Bechambi et al., 2016). ZnO has even shown better or comparable photocatalytic degradation than TiO2 (Shukla et al., 2010). This research work aims at designing of a sustainable, cost-effective and tuneable magnetic photocatalyst based on ace ZnO system. The series of Fe doped ZnO provides better structural and optical properties for efficient solar powdered degradation of Bisphenol A.
2. Experimental
2.1 Synthesis of bare and Fe doped ZnO The nanocrystalline FexZn1-xO(x=0.01, 0.03, 0.05) samples were prepared by solution combustion method. For CF1, 11.76g of Zinc nitrate (Zn (NO3)3.6H2O) and 0.161 g of Ferric
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
4
Nitrate (Fe(NO3)3.9H2O) taken as oxidizers in the combustion process were dissolved in 100mL distilled water whereas 8.10 g glycine (C2H5NO2) served as a fuel. Oxidiser/fuel ratio was kept at unity. The resulting mixture was allowed to heat at 100ºC with constant stirring. Finally, the dried powder was sintered in a muffle furnace at a temperature of 400ºC for 4 h. The amounts were varied accordingly for CF3 and CF5. For simplicity, notations CF1, CF3, and CF5 have been used for FexZn1-xO(x=0.01, 0.03, 0.05) samples. The resulting powder was grinded and characterised with various instrumental techniques. 2.2 Characterization X-ray powder diffraction analysis was conducted on an XPERTPRO diffractometer (XRD) using Cu-Kα radiation (λ=0.154 nm). Surface morphology was studied by scanning electron microscope using QUANTA250 FEI D9393 of the powder sample. Micro-structural features at high magnifications and selected area electron diffraction patterns were recorded using a transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) (JEOL, USA) operated at the electron accelerating voltage of 200 keV. The X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy was used for the chemical state determination and to check the electronic environment changes. The electrical properties were measured by putting the pellet between the spring loaded copper electrodes. By applying the dc voltage on the surfaces, current can be measured by using Keithley Source Meter 2611 model at room temperature as well as during the heating cycle upto 470 K. 2.3 Optical studies For optical studies, 0.005 g photocatalyst was suspended in ethanol. The suspension was then ultrasonicated for 2 h. The UV–visible spectrum was then recorded using a Systronics 2202 double -beam spectrophotometer. The direct band gaps were then calculated using the Tauc relation and band structure was also evaluated.

sections.heading: 2.4 Photodegradation of Bisphenol A (BPA) under solar light
sections.text:
In a typical experimental procedure photocatalyst (0.5g/L) were dispersed into 100 mL of solution containing 20 mgL-1 of BPA. The slurry was kept in the double wall cylinder equipped with a water circulation, placed on a magnetic stirrer and exposed to natural sunlight. The area of experiment is Solan, Himachal Pradesh, India- 30.9045ºN, 77.0967ºE in the Himalayan region. The experiments were performed in the month of April with average intensity of sunlight as 31 × 103 ± 100 lx. The sets were performed in a 90 min experiment. Thus though the intensity may vary a little but we have done all the experiments of pH, scavengers and comparison in a parallel fashion. Thus all the solutions are exposed to same condition. The absorbance was recorded (at 276 nm) using a double beam spectrophotometer

after collecting aliquots at different interval of times up to 90min. The chemical oxygen demand (COD) was measured by closed reflux method using potassium dichromate under acidic condition. After the oxidation step is completed, the amount of dichromate consumed is determined colorimetrically (which can also be determined volumetrically). The results are extracted by analyzing dichromate (hexavalent).
The total organic carbon (TOC) was analyzed using TOC 5000 analyzer, Shimadzu. After 45
min of photodegradation LC–MS analysis was carried out with a Thermo Scientific TSQ 8000 gas chromatograph–mass spectrometer. The degraded BPA solution was centrifuged and the intermediates were extracted using 5 mL of dichloromethane. Intermediates were then diluted by a mixture of 1:1 acetonitrile and water (containing 0.1% formic acid). The separation was performed on a Betabasic C18 column (150 mm X 2 mm) with a mobile phase flow rate of 0.5 ml min-1. 3. Results and Discussion 3.1. Structural study
Fig. 1 shows the X-Ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of prepared samples synthesized by solution combustion method. X-ray pattern revealed that all prepared samples have hexagonal wurtzite structure and the peaks could be indexed in accordance with JCPDS card no. 30- 1451. No extra peaks were found in the pattern which indicates the formation of single-phase structure for all samples. However the intensity of the characteristic peak of ZnO (002) structure decreases significantly with the iron content indicating a slight degradation of crystalline structure.
There is also a shift in peak position towards higher side of angle 2Ɵ and a slight decrease in the intensity of the peaks clearly indicates the incorporation of Fe at Zn site (inset Fig. 1). There is a possibility of a mixed valence state (II, III) for Fe. All structural parameters calculated theoretically are listed in Table 1. However the possibility of Fe cluster formation can’t be neglected without probing the structure of samples by other structural or micro - structural techniques like XPS and HRTEM analysis. To further confirm the phase purity and to collect the other structural changes, the observed XRD pattern was simulated with the help of FullProf software 2007. Rietveld refinements (Samariya et al., 2010) on the X-ray (XRD) data were done using the space group P 63 m c. Fig. 2 depicts the observed, calculated and difference XRD profiles for all samples after final cycle of refinement. It can be seen that the profiles for observed and calculated one are matching. The profile fitting procedure adopted

sections.heading: 3.2 Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) Analysis
sections.text: Transmission Electron Microscopy is used for the exact knowledge of particle size distribution present in the samples. TEM observations include low resolution micrographs, high resolution micrographs as well as selected area diffraction pattern. Fig. 3 presents the low resolution (left side) and high (right side) resolution transmission electron micrographs of prepared samples with various doping samples. Transmission electronic microscopy (TEM) micrograph of all samples shows that powders consist of agglomerated particles of 20-40 nm of rough, irregular but almost hexagonal in shape. Figure S1 shows the histogram of CF1, CF3 and CF5 showing size distribution. However the shape changes from hexagonal to spherical with greater Fe content. Right hand side of Fig. 3 shows the HRTEM images of all nanoparticles. A regular hexagonal lattice pattern can be clearly seen for the CF1 sample. We can clearly observe the d spacing which indicates the good crystallinity of the sample CF1. A slight degradation in the crystallinity and strain can be seen from CF1 to CF5 samples.

sections.heading: 3.3 X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis
sections.text:
XPS has been used for the determination of electronic structure (Karamat et al., 2009). Binding energies of photoelectrons are standardized with the aliphatic hydrocarbon C 1s peak at 285 eV. All XPS spectra were de-convoluted using XPSPEAK41 software for LorentzianGaussian fitting of asymmetric peaks by taking the Shirley background. Fig. 4 (a-b) presents the XPS survey spectra (in wide energy range 0-1300 eV) observed for CF1 and CF3 samples. The observed XPS survey spectrum reveals dominant peaks from Zn, C, O, and Fe elements thus confirming the chemical composition of samples. The core level spectra for all elements presents in the system have been studied to check the possibility of mixed valence states and the presence of any defects. The inset of Fig. 4 shows the core level spectra of Zn2p. The observed peak shapes of Zn2p exhibits high symmetry so there is no possibility of formation of mixture of ZnO, ZnFe2O4 and Fe3O4 as these phases possesses unsymmetrical peaks of Zn (Crist et al., 2000). So it rules out the possibility of ZnxFe3-xO4 in prepared

samples. Similar results have been observed for other samples also. Fig S2 presents the XPS spectrum of CF5 sample.
O 1s spectra In the normal environment, ZnO structure is generally associated with the oxygen vacancies. To further probe the structure oxygen core level XPS spectra is studied.
Fig. 5(c-d) presents the fitted O 1s XPS spectra. Broad and asymmetric nature of the O1s
peak suggests the presence of different co-ordination state of oxygen in the samples. Therefore, the observed spectra are fitted with the three Lorentzian–Gaussian peaks one for, a) low binding energy side of the O 1s spectrum to the O2− ions in the wurtzite structure of the hexagonal Zn2+ ion array, surrounded by zinc atoms with the full supplement of nearest neighbour O2− ions, b) The medium binding energy side is associated with the O2- ions in oxygen deficient regions within the matrix of ZnO, c) The higher binding energy component corresponds to the presence of the loosely bound oxygen species on the surface of the ZnO e.g. CO3 adsorbed H2O or O2. The O 1s XPS spectrum for CF5 is presented in Fig. S3. It can be observed from all three spectrums that similar type of oxygen environments exists in the samples. Fe 2p spectra Fig. 5 (a-b) which presents the Fe 2p XPS spectra, Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 peaks as well as their satellites are identified. These peak positions determine the local structure of the Fe atoms by providing information of the valence states. According to the hand book of XPS (Sun et al., 2015) and previously reported work, peaks of 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 for Fe 3+ are located at 724.3 and 710.7 eV and for Fe2+ at 722.3 and 709.3 eV. The peak position for metallic iron occurs at position of Fe 2p1/2 at 719.9 eV and Fe 2p3/2 at 706.5 eV (Kataoka et al., 2010). In the observed XPS spectra of CF1 sample Fe 2p 3/2 peak occurs at 710.43ev and Fe 2p 1/2 peak at 724.40eV.The corresponding satellite peaks centred at 712.87 eV and 712.15 eV which can be ascribed to the satellite peaks of Fe3+. Similar is the case of CF3 for which these peaks occur at 710.17, 712.20, 717.17 and 724.15eV. So, we can clearly interpret from the results that the major valence state of iron if 3+ in all the samples prepared by the combustion process. The shifting of these peaks towards lower side indicates the change of the valence state of Fe towards the Fe2+ with the greater Fe doping. Inference can be taken from the XPS analysis that iron exists in 3+ states in our samples which clearly suggests the presence of some nearby cationic species which converts the Fe2+ (in a defect free system) to Fe3+. This

sections.heading: 3.4 Electrical Properties
sections.text:
Electrical conductivity of ZnO can be mediated by several mechanisms. Electrical conductivity of oxide semiconductors such as ZnO ceramic varistor depends on the number and nature of oxygen vacancies that are generated during its synthesis process. It is well known that the electrical conductivity of ZnO at the room temperature is due to the presence of intrinsic defects created by oxygen vacancies, Zn interstitials, or extrinsic impurities (Dinesha et al., 2010). These defects are the source of donor states in the forbidden band slightly below the conduction band and hence resulting in the conducting behaviour of ZnO (Gupta et al., 1992). The dc electrical conductivity was calculated by the standard following relation (equation 1):

(1)
Where, V is the applied voltage, I is the measured current, A is the area of the pellet and t is thickness of the pellet (Soitah et al., 2010).
The calculated values for room temperature conductivity are of the order of 10-7(ohm-cm-1) for all samples. This order of conductivity is attributed to the presence oxygen vacancies generated during the combustion process involved in the synthesis route (Sukkar et al., 1982). A decrease of electrical conductivity (at room temperature) is observed with iron Fe doping, which can be due to the presence of major Fe3+ state as work as deep donors and results into depression of intrinsic donor concentration levels (Table 3). Reduction in crystallite size as deduced from TEM micrographs is another candidate. With the reduction in the crystallite size there will be increase in the grain boundaries resulting in the more electrical barriers. Also, the decrease in the conductivity of Fe-doped ZnO can be explained as follows: when ZnO is substituted with Fe ions which are in the 3+ ion valence state, they replace the Zn2+ ions and occupy zinc interstitial sites. The substituted Fe atoms cannot be easily ionized like zinc atoms because of their higher ionization potential (2 eV). There exists a contradictory opinion between different authors who presents various mechanisms for room temperature electrical conductivity of ZnO. According to the Simpson and Cordero (Naeem et al., 2007), oxygen vacancies are the major cause for conductivity of ZnO. On the other hand, there
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
9
exists a different opinion which states that Zinc interstitials play a major role in conductivity. The applicability of different models for explaining the conduction mechanism can be evaluated through the study of the temperature dependence of the electrical conductivity. The Arrhenius plot (Fig. 6 a-c) shows different slopes in the low and the high temperature region which shows the presence of two different conduction mechanisms. The linear fit shows that the thermally activated conduction is the dominant conduction mechanism in the high temperature region. The deviation from the linear fit indicates that thermal activation mechanism is not valid for the low temperature region. Next candidate for conduction mechanism may be VRH (variable range hopping mechanism). The presence of two different conduction mechanisms suggests the availability of two types of donor levels which are shallow as well as deep donor levels in the band gap of ZnO. Thus Fe doped ZnO pelletized samples has semiconducting characteristics which is attributed to the presence of intrinsic defects like oxygen vacancies (singly ionized or doubly ionized) and zinc interstitials as supported by XPS analysis.

sections.heading: 3.5 Magnetic Studies
sections.text:
Vibrating sample magnetometer measures the prominent magnetic parameters such as saturation magnetisation, coercive field strength, remenance in the form of hysteresis curve (M vs H loop). These parameters also suggest the soft or hard nature of materials together with the idea of paramagnetism, ferromagnetism, superparamagnetism. Fig. 7(a) shows the magnetic-field dependence of the magnetization (M versus H) at room temperature (300K) for CF1, CF3 and CF5 samples. The diamagnetic contribution from the sample holder has been subtracted from the raw data. The observed paramagnetic like behaviour can be assigned to the actual incorporation of Fe ions into the otherwise diamagnetic ZnO structure; although the precipitation of an anti-ferromagnetic phase cannot be ruled out. No ferromagnetic curve was obtained even after increasing Fe content. But if we check these loops particularly at low magnetic fields, a very weak coercivity was observed in this case indicating a clear discrepancy between pure paramagnetic behaviour (Fig. 7b). So we assign this behaviour as weak ferromagnetic + paramagnetic behaviour. For a pure antiferromagnetic compound, there should be linear dependence of magnetization with applied magnetic field. It is worth noticing that CF1 sample has coercive field of the order of 100 Oe and it changes to 33 Oe, 10Oe with increasing Fe doping content. Such value of field can’t be due to the instrumental error. The variation of coercive field is in accordance with the particles size reduction. It is visible from the large view of the curves at low field that these M-H curves are not symmetrical about the origin suggesting the role of shape

10
anisotropy also. These results can be explained in the view of polaron percolation theory. According to the theory, polaron percolation threshold (δp) and the cation percolation threshold (xp ) are the two major landmarks of the magnetic phase diagram. If the number of magnetic cations are large enough, ferromagnetic ordering can occur depending upon the condition δ< δp and x<xp. For cation threshold x<xp, long range ordering cannot be created by the antiferromagnetic super exchange. So, in the view of percolation theory, it can be concluded that in the glycine assisted combustion synthesis, polaron –polaron threshold distance may not be large enough to create strong ferromagnetic ordering.

sections.heading: 3.6 Optical studies
sections.text:
Fig 8(a) shows the Tauc plots (Sharma et al., 2015) as derived from UV-visible spectrum of ZnO, CF1, CF3 and CF5. The optical band gap for ZnO, CF1, CF3 and CF5 is 3.25 eV, 3.10 eV, 2.83 eV and 2.63 eV respectively. The band gap of bulk ZnO is 3.3 eV which is higher in nano-ZnO in this work. In general optical band gap of nanoparticles is higher than bulk semiconductor (Azimi et al., 2015). However in our case nano ZnO has a lower band gap which is due to crystal defects and vacancies on the crystal and has been observed in other experiments too (Kant et al., 2014). It is observed that the optical band gap of ZnO nanocrystals is decreased on increasing the dopant concentration. As optical band gap of bare ZnO nanoparticles lies in UV region, photocatalytic activity is expected to be low. However on increasing the Fe concentration the absorbance shifts in visible region because of narrow band gap. Substitution of Fe cations can modify the environment of Zn in ZnO lattice and affect its electronic band structure and introduce oxygen vacancies. These oxygen vacancies and dopant ions may trap electrons and thus decreased electron hole pair recombination. The band edge potentials of photocatalyst were calculated using the equation 2 & 3 (Kumar et al., 2017)

The band structure parameters for bare and doped ZnO are listed in Table 3. Fig. 8 (b) represents the band structure of ZnO, CF1, CF3 and CF5. The CB edge of ZnO lies at -0.10 eV and shifts to -0.04 eV for CF1 photocatalyst. In case of CF3

and CF5 the CB edges are at 0.13 eV and 0.27 eV. On solar exposure, electron-hole pairs are generated. The electrons from valence band get excited to conduction band. With decrease in band gap the electron hole recombination is expected. However from XPS results it is observed that loosely bound oxygen vacancies in CF3 are increased and presence of iron in +3 oxidation state and zinc interstitials leads to electron scavenging. This leads to a charge separation, increased transport of carriers and a reduced recombination. However in case of CF5 the band gap is further reduced which may lead to higher recombination.

sections.heading: 3.7 Photo-degradation of BPA under solar light
sections.text:
The photocatalytic activity of bare and Fe doped ZnO was analyzed by degradation of endocrine disruptor Bisphenol A (structure given in Fig S5) under natural sunlight. Plain photolysis of BPA (Fig S6) under solar light shows a meagre degradation of 4.6% which shows higher stability of the pollutant. The removal of BPA was studied under three conditions: Adsorption, equilibrium adsorption followed by photocatalysis and synergistic adsorption cum photo-degradation. The adsorption potential of ZnO, CF1, CF3 and CF5 is represented in Fig S7 (a) which shows that all the photocatalysts have poor adsorption capacity. In the second reaction condition the reaction system was first kept for 1 hour in dark to establish adsorption-desorption equilibrium and then exposed to sunlight. The results are given in Fig S7 (b). It is observed that a degradation of 61.1% in presence of ZnO nanoparticles is observed in 2 hours of experiment. However degradation increases to 77.2% (CF1) and 99.1% (CF3). However CF5 scores poor (90.4%) as compared to CF3 despite its lower band gap.
Photo-catalytic activity of undoped ZnO is generally attributed both to the donor states caused by the some defect sites such as oxygen vacancies and interstitial zinc atom and to the acceptor states which arise from zinc vacancies and interstitial oxygen atom.
In the third reaction condition the reaction system was directly exposed to sunlight without keeping in dark. This facilitates simultaneous or synergistic adsorption and photocatalysis. The results are given in Fig 9(a). 98.4% of BPA was degraded in 90 min exposure in presence of CF3. The reactivity order for various photocatalysts follows order: CF3 (98.4%) > CF5 (85.6%) > CF1 (77.1%) > ZnO (61.9%).
Adsorption also plays a role in the photocatalytic process. During the simultaneous adsorption and catalysis the concentration of the pollutant was measured by the amount

Where V is the solution volume (mL) and m is the mass of the adsorbent (g) In a typical mechanism, on solar exposure electrons and holes are generated in the semiconductor which leads to formation of ●O-2 & ●OH radicals in addition to H2O2, ●OOH etc. as reactive oxygen species. This leads to disruption of conjugation in organic pollutant and mineralization thereof. This is represented in scheme 1. The O2 - react with H+ to form hydrogen peroxide radicals (•HO2) (scheme1) which leads to formation of hydrogen peroxide. Hydrogen peroxide is a better electron acceptor than oxygen and reduces the chance of oxygen recombination (Zhang et al., 2004). Scheme 3 shows the Fenton reactions possible. However it may be possible that it may be mere effect of hydrogen peroxide reacting with photogenerated electrons and holes. But there can be a Fenton possibility. These series of reactions lead to decreased recombination and increase in reactive oxygen species. As per predicted mechanism and band edge positions, HO● have been demonstrated to play major role in the degradation of BPA.
The overall degradation process under synergistic adsorption and photocatalytic system follows pseudo first order kinetics which is represented in Fig 9(b). The rate order follows following order: CF3 (0.0253 min-1) > CF5 (0.01084 min-1) > CF1 (0.00925 min-1). CF3 behaves as best photocatalyst under both the reaction conditions.
As per band structure (Fig 8b) the band gap decreases in order ZnO>CF1>CF3>CF5. With decrease in band gap the visible absorption increases which is the major part of solar spectrum. Hence the photocatalysis is expected to accelerate. The effect of transition metal ions as dopants on the photo-catalytic activity is the result of electron–hole recombination and interfacial charge transfer across interface. Doping a photocatalyst with a certain amount of metal improves the migration efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs. In addition ferric ions and zinc interstitials (as evident from XPS analysis) behave act as electron traps and reduce recombination. Thus it leads to higher concentration of hydroxyl

Scheme 2: Fenton mechanism Degree of metal dispersion on the surface of particle and the homogeneity of the chemical composition of a single particle depend mainly on the doping procedures, calcinations temperature, thus leading to different morphological and crystalline structures (Naeem et al., 2006; Ahn et al., 2006) As understood by our HRTEM, XPS, and electrical results the concentration of holes are more than the electrons in the doped samples, so, the less recombination rate is expected for greater Fe doped samples. For CF3 photocatalyst the presence of loosely bound oxygen vacancies, zinc interstitials leads to reduced recombination and higher photoactivity. In case of CF5 the degradation falls because of lower band gap leading to higher recombination. Previously it has been reported that higher dopant concentration or impurities act as centers of recombination of electrons and holes leading to decrease of degradation rate. By increasing the molar percentage of Fe from 1-3% the degradation activity increases and decreases when the concentration increases to 5%. The electron-hole pairs are liberated in ZnO which can be migrated to Fe3O4 or Fe2O3 levels leading to a reduced recombination (Mohammadyari et al., 2015) because of formation of a Z-scheme junction. The junction can be between ZnO & Fe@ZnO or ZnO & Fe3O4/Fe2O3.

This can also be interpreted in other sense the increased dopant ions would increase more traps for holes.
The CB of ZnO (-0.10 eV) and CF1 (-0.04 eV) is negative. The redox potential of E(O2/ ●O2 - ) = -0.33 eV) which is closer to CB edges of ZnO and CF1. Thus superoxide radical anions can be generated though to lesser extent as edges are less negative. However, the CB edges are positive for CF3 (0.13 eV) and CF5 (0.27 eV). The standard redox potential of top valence band of ZnO and CFx is higher than ●OH/H2O (2.27 eV vs NHE) (Cui et al., 2012) and ●OH/-OH (1.99 eV vs NHE) (Fu et al., 2008). Thus photo-generated holes are thus capable of producing hydroxyl radicals both from hydroxyl ions and water. In first reaction condition we observe poor results for the same photocatalysts. The adsorption takes place first in this case. The photocatalytic efficiency is generally accelerated by adsorption of adsorbate onto the photocatalyst (Raizada et al., 2014). Figure S8 shows the porous SEM image of CF3 and figure S9 shows the BET isotherm for CF3. The specific surface area of CF3 is 57m2/g. The higher surface area of catalyst favours high adsorption. However the rate is influenced by presence or absence of vacant sites on the surface of photocatalyst. In this condition system there is possibility that the surface of photocatalyst gets covered by pollutant and so degradation gets suppressed in subsequent time. However in synergistic adsorption and photocatalysis, BPA first gets adsorbed and then degraded simultaneously by attack of reactive oxygen species. Effect of pH on the degradation of BPA in presence of CF3 (best performing catalyst) was also studied and is given in Fig 9(c). Highest removal was obtained at pH =7. Dynamic light scattering technique was used to determine the polarity of photo-catalyst in pH 5-6 and 7-8. The surface of both the catalysts is positively charged in pH range 6-7 and negative in higher pH range. The pKa value for BPA is 9.6 at pH 7. This means that means the surface is nearly neutral or slightly positive at this pH. However at higher pH both the catalyst and the pollutants will be negatively charged and thus decrease the adsorption. At very low pH BPA will be protonated and could also lead to leaching of the photocatalyst..

sections.heading: 3.8 Effect of hydrogen peroxide & scavengers
sections.text:
Batch experiments were also carried out to have an insight into reaction mechanism. In typical photo-catalytic mechanism, a series of oxidation-reduction reactions take place and in addition to electrons, holes, reactive oxygen species as ●O2 - , ●OH etc. are generated. H2O2 is has been an integral part of the photodegradation. It would lead to formation of more ●OH
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
15
radicals upon photolysis (Amiri-Alireza et al., 2015). However at higher peroxide concentration rate falls due to reaction with hydroxyl radicals. To study the role of various species effect of scavengers as KI (as hole and surface hydroxyl radical scavenger) (Chen et al., 2011), 4-hydroxy-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidinyloxy (TEMPOL) (●O-2 scavenger) Isopropanol (IPA) (●OHads scavenger) (Wang et al., 2012) on degradation process in presence of CF3 under synergistic system was studied. Fig 9(d) shows the effect of scavengers on degradation of BPA. It is observed that in presence of IPA the rate of degradation is reduced to 46%. Similarly degradation decreased to 10.3% in presence of KI. This means hydroxyl free radicals are the major attacking species. However, the surface free radicals play more important role than those in bulk. The greater inhibition of the reaction through alcohol and KI as radical scavenger indicates that HO* plays a more important role in the photocatalytic degradation of BPA (Yang et al., 2009). However the surface free radicals play more important role than those in bulk. In general because of the adsorption power of IPA in aqueous solution, their direct oxidation is not achieved (Derikvandi et al., 2017). The presence of TEMPOL and IPA leads to fall in the degradation which shows that both are the reactive species involved. The effect of scavengers is represented in scheme 3. In addition the presence of hydrogen peroxide leads to higher and faster degradation of BPA which is due to higher production of hydroxyl free radicals. Fig 10 shows pictorial representation of overall degradation process of BPA under natural sunlight.

Scheme 3: Effect of scavengers Fig 11(a) shows the absorption spectrum of BPA in presence of CF3 under synergistic adsorption and photocatalysis condition. The absorbance clearly decreases, with time with loss of characteristic peak after 90 min of exposure. The degradation of BPA was also studied in presence of commercial photocatalysts P-25 (20-40 nm) and ZnO (20-40 nm) (Fig 11 b). In case of P-25, 58.3% and for ZnO 56.2 % of BPA was removed. Thus CF3 behaves as better photocatalyst. However, many hybrid catalysts have been developed these days but tuning of popular photocatalyst ZnO by doping leads to designing of a cheap and efficient photocatalyst. The catalyst is also magnetically recoverable. A comparison of phototodegradation activity of CF3 with other experiments shows that CF3 is a better candidate because it performs excellent under solar illumination. It is observed that in most experiments ZnO or TiO2 has been used under UV light. However in this experiment, high removal of BPA has been removed in solar light. The comparison is given in Table 4.The catalyst is simple, cheap and tuneable.

sections.heading: 3.9 Mechanistic pathway of degradation and Reusability
sections.text:
The effect of scavengers, micro-structural analysis and band structure suggests a mechanistic pathway of degradation. Results are confirmed by TOC, COD and GC-MS analysis. The

TOC and COD removal are represented in Fig 12 (a). In presence of CF3, 45.3% of TOC was removed and COD reduced to 11.2%. This suggests mineralization of BPA in longer experiment. Based on the intermediates detected in GC-MS spectrum (Fig 12 b) a reaction mechanism is predicted in scheme 4. The intermediates are listed in Table 5. In a typical mechanism •OH radicals may attack BPA to produce phenol, p-hydroxyacetophenone, phydroxy benzaldehyde p-hydroquinone, p-isopropenylphenol, 4-hydroxyphenyl-2-propanol etc may lead to mineralization in form of simple moieties as acetic acid, ethanol, formic acid carbon dioxide etc.

Scheme 4: Mechanistic pathway of degradation of BPA The reusability of CF3 photocatalyst (Fig 12 c) was studied for six consecutive cycles. The separation was made with help of magnet and then treated with ethanol and distilled water to remove the adsorbed pollutant. A meagre decrease of 2% in degradation was observed for CF3 after sixth cycle. Thus photo-catalyst is stable, efficient and reusable.

4. Conclusions
In summary, we report that opted synthesis route which involves combustion in air has resulted into less concentration of defects which accounts for high resistivity of the samples. The porous Fe doped ZnO semiconductor with high photo-activity and decent surface area proves to be an efficient powerful degradation of endocrine disruptor BPA under natural sunlight. CF3 proves to be a best photocatalyst in the series with optimum band gap and effective band edge positions. Ferric ions, interstitial zinc and oxygen vacancies lead to higher photon capture and reduced recombination in doped ZnO. Band structure analysis promises to design future photocatalysts to be used in real systems for various applications. In this work we achieve:
• Combustion synthetic route to form CFx series • Band structure analysis–depicting shifts in band gap and band edges • CF3- best photocatalyst for BPA degradation-better than commercial P-25 and ZnO • Hydroxyl radicals as major attacking species • Higher COD removal-mineralization thereof • Stable, cheap and reusable catalyst
